segments.text: I believe I'm really working hard at it.
three, four weeks myself.
But I felt very smart because this guy was, you know, really needing help.
So I helped him through his little beginning struggles and so on.
And by the way, the next time I saw him, he was doing some fabulous stuff.
And I watched him.
I said, my God.
First of all, I said, how are you doing?
He said, I'm doing it.
I looked what he was doing.
I couldn't believe it.
And it turned out that he was, he had helped build computers.
He knew everything about it.
He knew it, except
that he didn't know how to log in.
I mean, that's a little thing you have to learn.
And so he became, in a way, a kind of... He taught me a lot of things.
We became friends.
And I got him... He was a Milton scholar in the English grad school.
But he's really interested to lay here.
And I got him appointed as a computer adjunct to the English department.
And he did a lot of important things for us.
And he helped found this IRIS school.
And they developed a hypertext software called Intermedia.
And a professor friend of mine, George Landau, got interested in this stuff.
Landau's famous.
Yeah, yeah.
Well, Landau was involved with IRIS.
helped to develop Intermedia and was the first to use it.
So, in the late 80s, he was urging me to get into it myself and teach a course.
Well,
That was kind of more than I wanted to get involved with.
It looked kind of complicated.
My own, you know, things to do.
And I thought, well, I'll get a student, right?
There was a student who was very keen on getting into it, a grad student, and I wanted to get him a teaching job for a year, teaching a beginning hypertext workshop.
And I failed.
I cried, and he said, no, if you apply for it, it might do well.
We can't do this for a student.
So I went away on a sabbatical.
And I came back, and I had a...
a free course to choose.
I was teaching a workshop and I could teach something else.
I ran into Landau and the course of it was, all right, I'll have a go.
But at this time, I still had never had a mouse in my hand.
I had no idea about these things.
I'd never played with Windows at all.
I was still a DOS user thoroughly.
I'd created my own macros and so on inside DOS, but I had no idea.
I'd never, this is pre-Windows, and I'd never...
dinner on a Mac and just looked over people's shoulders at him.
So I taught, of course, and I taught on Macs, because you had that window.

I got an assistant, a senior undergraduate, who was badgering me to be his undergraduate advisor for his thesis, and I was turning him down, and then we got into his hypertext stuff, and he said, wouldn't you like a TA for that course?
He said, yeah, he had Landau's course, so he made a deal.
I would be his advisor, he'd be my TA.
That fellow is Robert Arellano, who is still there.
Well, Bobby is really, really good, and I've managed over the years to keep finding him.
So he's on a presidential fellowship there now for three years, and teaching my hypertension workshops on the way.
So he was my team.
We had a class, and we had about ten students, brave students, decided to have a go.
They didn't know what this was, and I didn't know what it was.
And there was nothing quite published.
There were a couple of things that Eastgate was producing at that time, but Michael Joyce's afternoon was still handed around to us.
It wasn't, you know, it wasn't, well, I think, in fact, at least it was just about to publish it.
The copy we had was stuff that was, somebody had a copy and they'd pass it around.
So all of the early hypertext fiction was still in the developmental stage.
And there was a group at Brown, which I often went to their meetings, called CHUG, Computers and Humanities Users Group.
And CHUG, CHUG invited...
people to come talk about computer issues and humanities, and library issues very typically, for example.
I was aware of how libraries were changing back in the mid to late 80s, attending those meetings.
And Stuart Malthrop and Michael Joyce, they had been invitees, so I'd seen a bit what they were doing.
and they left stuff behind which I looked at.
So we had some sense of it.
We didn't know really.
I was completely unaware of what would happen and that's what that first piece was based on was that kind of opening experience, opening awareness of how the stuff worked.
I don't confess to my 60s involvement with a similar idea but that's what made it easy so that I was not
I was not surprised at the possibility.
In fact, they looked like enhancements that were attractive.
And just to go back, what did you call that machine?
Did you have a name for that machine?
Well, it was just edge-knots cards, and you used a punch and steel needles.
That's all.
And it was basically an early database?
Yeah, yeah.
It was a database idea.
And in fact, it was a kind of...
hand-punched way of doing what was developing shortly thereafter, in the early 70s, were those computer cards that you'd see.
I don't know if you ever saw the composer's work.
I was at Princeton for a year and got to know Babbitt and all his people there and had this electronic, the Princeton-Columbian electronic music center.
And the computer music was just catching on.
It's a new idea.
But it was done with these immense decks of punched cards.
I mean, immense decks of punched cards to get a little bit of sound.
I mean, it wasn't to get much.
It was just a huge thing.
Well, mine was like an even more primitive version of that because those punches, at least you could order up these.
I had to actually get the punch out and look like that.
Was it an exercise for you or was it actually useful as a retrieval system for information?
It would have been.

very useful but for the fact that the punching took a lot longer than the note-taking and it led to ideas you'd be take a card that would have i don't know about hypertext let's say i had written some notes about it and i would see that there would be reason to punch it for reasons of uh of hypertext and for reasons of computers writing but also maybe because of its content for reasons of uh of um
oh, I don't know, some social issue or some question about time and space or whatever.
And the more I thought about the way to punch it, of course, I'd get more and more punches, I would think of new notes to take.
So I'd be writing six or seven notes while I was working to punch the one card.
So I ended up with lots of unpunched cards in a few of them.
That was my problem.
And I probably had, in the end, generated a few thousand cards and still exist like three-by-fives, really, because...

I figured out the binary idea was a way to do something fast and so that if it was bibliography or if it was certain kinds of content or something like that it didn't say anything else at least yeah I could find it through that down the narrow edge I had about 12 or 16 punches here that I divided up into things that were quick
access of a comic.
I said, well, that was something about history or something about, you know, those kind of large topics.
So I could needle those out in a hurry, and I did manage to punch those up pretty quickly.
So most of the cards have one punch on the other side, but that's about it.
Now, as a novelist, as a traditional linear print sense, do you have a sense of permanence?
I mean, do you have a permanence of the text
of what you created and having it be made of that?
Well, yes and no.
I mean, the permanence of the text will exist in the computer.
It won't exist on paper.
So already there's a kind of anomaly about it that what we think of as permanence has already moved to light anyhow.
To light.
To light.

There will always be, as there are still monastery libraries with valuable manuscripts under glass, there will always be this kind of respect for the Gutenberg tradition as it moves into its museum status.
It's a very cumbersome technology relative to the movement of light.
Moving a book, moving the volume.
around, hundreds of these things around, in trucks, using up petrol and shelf space and warehouse space and so on, is incredibly cumbersome compared to computer storage.
So, I think publishing, for example, years ago I asked publishers, I mean, just before I even got into hypertext,
in the late 80s, I was asking, why are they actually publishing their books?
Why don't you get the bookstores to do the publishing?
They provide, you provide your text by computer, in other days by disk, now by email, provide them the text and they can do the printing and binding and so on.
There's no need to have this huge warehousing and pulping and having all these stocks, but of course,
business is used to owning things that they sell.
They're not, you know, toothpaste or toilet paper or books.
And so they think of it as, you don't have product, it's not, you know, they're getting out of that finally, but they couldn't kind of perceive that.
Now it's going to happen.
And I think in the next decade, not even the same millennium,
there will be increasing publishing by the bookstores, and the bookchains especially, they may actually start hiring their own little editorial staffs and just do it straight.
And the idea will be that with a kind of inexpensive binding mechanism and cover design can also be done computerized and moved by light, they will produce all the books in their bookstores.
You come in, you'll come in and say,
I would like a copy of this.
There'll be a sample copy.
I'd like a copy of that and come back in the afternoon.
It's there.
I went to the MIT Media Lab for this book, this project I'm working with.
There's a young man there, 29 years old, and he's hitting the project called the e-book, the electronic book.
I've heard of this.
And it will look like a regular codex.
And they said they're two or three years away from it, and they're doing this with electronic ink.
And you will load each one of these volumes that you'll buy with a little chip.
It'll have 3,000 books in it.
And you dial up the book that you want.
And then each page, we have a paper or a text book.
You'll read the book.
And each page will be a screen.
And we're working on this.
My wife, in fact, found this item, and I went to...
But we're still talking about... Soft screens.
And we're still talking about discrete work that is not changing.
I guess when I... I say between hypertextual... When I'm talking about permanence, I'm talking about artistic recreation and expression.
There's no need for hypertextual change, either.
I mean, the interactivity that's so much brooded about is not necessarily a standard feature of this stuff.
The...
There is.
We're having, in fact, I'm getting a conference on these issues at Brown next spring.
Inviting a lot of the techies in and mixing them up with writers so that we try to get the right... Right now, much of this is, especially as seen on the Internet, is...
It's hostile to text, and the idea of text, yeah, and the idea of text of any kind is hostile to anything that isn't Victorian or oral.
And to try to create a warmer atmosphere for this in the way they develop any technology.
The issue arises about the future of fiction, and there is a strong feeling amongst a lot of people.
The future of fiction looks a little like games play, and therefore it is instable, and it does have a lack of permanence in a sense.
Each text continues to develop as the games players play with it.
But there's another kind of narrative art which exists inside

um the hypertextual medium that is itself a fixed entity is not it's not read twice the same as a 10 meters print book it's just uh it exists as a as a whole finished and enclosed thing one of the things we we do about

doing my hyper-fictional effects, which are really focused on not the games-playing metaphor, but upon the traditional narrative metaphors, is to ask, how do you achieve organicity in such a fluid medium?
I mean, when you have a reader entering into your narrative space with so many possibilities, the way they can approach the text,
How do you not having the support of the page-turning mechanism create a feeling of an organic whole?
And this is a terrible challenge.
It's not easy.
Do people experience this today?
Is there a reader of the future that has to be required to come along with the fiction of the future?
I mean, are there people that enjoy this kind of reading experience today?
Oh, yeah.
Is it an artistic sense?
I don't know how, I don't know how.
Or recreational sense?
I'm wondering what it is.
Well, most of it's recreational still.
In terms of readers, I mean, not in terms of writers.
Better writers.
But then, it's true of books.
I mean, it's true of books.
All the great writers, few of the great writers I know have any audience.
And that's even true of great writers in the past who've got to
vertical audience through time.
They've got tremendous respect amongst a few people in each generation, but are not widely read.
Dampty's still not a bestseller.
Shakespeare comes close in this country, but not most other places, but Cervantes.
I mean, you can almost, there's almost no writer who at any given moment
in time had sold widely.
A letter we would describe as a great letter.
Well, one that the permanence of his text means something.
A lot of permanent texts could just as well be done, because, you know, there's a lot of crap that's kept as permanent texts.

And it's kind of this awesome respect for the book that emerged out of the way the book evolved out of the Middle Ages, out of the panastic libraries, the secrets hidden away that one would anticipate existed in the book once everybody could get their hands on it.
You know, how the book of Revelations might be really understood as a now contemporary language.
And the Kabbalah idea.
And...
That awe for books, with terrible crimes and burning books and so on, that we feel is misplaced in a large sense.
There's a lot of rubbish that really should be put back in the toilet paper.
But we don't do it because we know nobody can make the judgment.
What gets booked is apt to be the best stuff.
kind of rat, not the worst.
The computer, of course, voids all of that, because nothing needsnow we really have permanents, right before, books decay in libraries, you get burnt out for single copies banished, and so on.
That needs never happening, but now we do have a true program.
Well, except that there is a question that we don't.
I mean, a lot of the stories we see
We see data taken from some of these space probes.
It's not even 15 years old, and they can't even access it.
It's deteriorating.
There is no guarantee that... No, there never is.
There never is.
I agree.
All I meant was that the technology itself works
as a more efficient library than the libraries do.
That's what I mean, in your doing of libraries.
And that although, of course, they fail to everything, to everything human fails, they have more of a chance of achieving those goals that those are desirable goals.

than our traditional methods i know there's a lot of problems first one of the things the main issue that we're bringing up in our brown conference is standards because one of the huge problems is changing standards um that all the stuff i did after i've got to move now to windows and uh
it'll eventually become more or less unreadable, even though it exists on disks, backup disks, and so on.
People will have to find old programs to read, which, you know, may not be easily accessible.
It's like lost languages or stuff like any new kinds of translators.
But one of the standards that was a kind of amazing standard, I remember
I remember it was fairly recently, it must have been, well, within the last five years or so, someone pointed out to me that asking ASCII is only like 20 years old or something like that.
It's very recent.
I mean, it's a really, really recent idea.
And yet it's old.
Yeah, it's the oldest thing we've got, really, in a way.
And you worry that, what if suddenly that were changed?
If you moved from that to something else, because something would be more efficient, what would be the consequences of that?
And, of course, it would immediately make inaccessible just vast areas.
It doesn't mean that you couldn't quite quickly translate everything into the new and discard the old.
That's one of the great advantages, if you don't have to
It doesn't have irreplaceable physical content.
Its physical content is, as with all digitized information, is in its reproduction.
We will eventually digitize everything, smells and technical stuff.

So all of our central experiences can be in some manner digitized, but it only means that you put a code in that can somehow, something at the other end can actually translate that code back into the real things.
So that if you put in the note C, you know, in digitized form, it comes out C on some loudspeak, some system that reads it and reproduces that sound.
So anything like tactile experiences or anything that has to do with our information exchange can be digitized and reproduced, provided at the other end there is something that can reproduce it.
And that's always the difficult thing, why we do these complicated suits and
you know, glasses and so on for virtual reality, is because the hard part is not digitizing, but undigitizing.
You might get back into something.
So, the problem of standard shifts and tape deterioration and so on really is not an impossible one to answer, because we're not dealing with
with objects that have to be in some way preserved.
We're dealing with the spec-wise tape that that stuff is stored on.
But basically, we're dealing with something that can be translated quickly into any other kind of form.
The term they use now is migration.
Someone has to be assured of the migration tape.
They say it's always zeros and ones in the China system.
I went through this at Cornell, and they were all headshots up there.
This whole thing was going on.
Well, in fact, Piper took it again.
Well, not hypertext.
The real use of it became up there, because hypertext began with Ted Nelson, who came to Brown, actually, at a very critical moment, his career in Brown's development.
He was brought there by a graphics man called Andrews Van Damme, Andy Van Damme.
Andy was one of the early pioneers in computer graphics.
And Nelson came and did a...
a lot of research in hypertextual form.
Have you read his work at all?
No.
Computer Lib, and, um... I didn't bring along it.
By email, I'll send you.
Okay.
Well, there's a conversation out on the web right now.
I participated in it.
It was called, um...

rethinking ted nelson or something like that so i'll send you the uh i'll send you the url for that it's it's speed magazine speed feed f-e-e-d and uh they deal with four of his different four concepts thinker toys idea and his links and he was the guy that developed the whole idea of hypertext his invention the word this is

was a kind of 60s guru for all this stuff and but at cornell uh is where they formed up this little group with extra stewart and most of i think i don't know story the nancy kaplan in her kitchen she now lives with the first gatherings of these people began and this is so important
Well, I'm writing about Cornell, and they just seem to come up in this context every place I've seen.
My son was a Cornell grad, so I got to know Cornell well.
But Nancy's now in Baltimore.
She lives with Stuart Miltrup, who's the Cypotex guy.
She's a very bright woman.
If you're doing all this stuff, she'd be a good person to talk to.
Kaplan?
Kaplan, yeah.
K-A-P-L-A-N?
Yeah.
At Hopkins, you said?
No, at the University of Baltimore.
University of Baltimore.
Yeah.
Well, Stuart's there, too, and Stuart's very good to talk to.
I think Stuart's the wisest and most innovative of all the hypertext writers right now.
Stuart Malthrop.
M-O-U-L-T-H-R-O-P.
This is his novel I talk about here.
which I found much too academic, Victory Garden.
But he's moved away from that immensely.
He's working very vigorously out on the net, which is a hard thing to do.
It's a very hard environment to work in.
And he's really trying to subvert and convert it.
And he's a very valuable person.
You've got how many novels here?
I don't know if it's heavy.
A dozen, perhaps?
More than that.
What's the more exciting medium for you to write in now?
Well, it's not so much exciting.
I tend to work on several things at once and have done since I began writing them.
And it means that there are like 50 to 100 projects unfinished always.
They're all sitting there like ideas or paragraphs or chapters or something that should be done.
What I was looking at now, I'm trying to work on a piece that I began in 1969 when I moved here.
I just made a movie, a documentary film at Iowa, called On a Confrontation in Iowa City.
It had to do with the Vietnam War protests.
And this was in the 60s?
Yeah.
I shot it all, and I had helped develop the film, and I had A and B wrote it, and I'd done it all.
I just wanted to learn everything I could learn about filmmaking at that time.
So I came away with a story idea, which I began then when I moved here, and interrupted it to work on a public burning, I thought, for six months, and five, six years went by.
And then I would keep taking it with me every while I went and working on it, but then something else would take over it.
I went to Venice with it, and Penopio to Fulbright, etc.
And so I brought it here again.
Now that's, you know, we're 30 years later, and I'm still working on this text.
It's in the form of nine novellas, really, long novellas.
It's about a pornographic film we wrote.
Link to use the current text?
No, no, not really.
It's very narrative, very much a book narrative.
in which this pornographic film hero, his whole life has lived in film, and the films, each of the time, are made by a different woman filmmaker.
So there's nine women making these films.
And it's very hard work.
It's very, very hard work.
So it's one reason I resist it all the time and do something else instead.
But because I have so many of these sorts of things, it's never been a huge temptation to really get into writing about things.
I like teaching it.
I like to see what happens to students' heads when they get into it.
They become much better readers, much better writers.
Do they?
Oh, it transforms that perception of what... I used to, back in the 60s, I used to teach a course, I still taught it right up into the late 80s, called Exemplary Ancient Fictions.
And we read creation myths and...
The Gilgamesh Epic, and Enuma Elish, and Book of Genesis, and Greek stories, and myths, and Romans, and all the metamorphoses, and folktales, and various things on up to medieval romance.
And the whole idea of this thing was it was a writing course.
They had to do a certain amount of academic work, but they also had to do some creative work.

The whole idea was to work with writers to help them understand narrative strategies that were pre-Servantes was my cutting off point, and to perceive the possibility of narrative beyond what was, in those days,
the standard form.

As of before, Star Trek movies and, you know, a lot of things that might have inspired the imagination just weren't there, and that we had these kind of dull, insistent repetitions of the past in terms of form.
And the inability to see, until we worked at it, how conventional the so-called well-made story or the novel was.
I mean, it was not something that was natural, as often felt to be, but depended
I didn't use the words in those days, but the Pentagon booked technology for the feeling of being in the right place, you know, being the right thing for that medium.
But we were working on forms that escaped this limitation.
And those ancient sections we'd work all semester long, and only sort of in closing moments of weeks.
the light would begin to dawn, and something would begin to happen with the writing that would escape this limitation.
Undergraduates were more quick to catch on, but the grad students were dreadful.
They were so ironclad already in their notion of what writing ought to be.
I taught my first hyperfiction workshop, and the first week it was over.
I mean, that part was done.
You just sat down and you started, and what happened?
I mean, there was a sudden awareness about form.
You start with nothing, and so you have to build everything.
If you want line, you've got to put it there.
And the discovery of that, and the discovery, therefore, of how reading was done, and how writing fed the reading, and how the form dictated both,
was suddenly, or the technology dictated the form of the table, was suddenly transparent.
And so the leap is sort of instantaneous and simply non-problematic.
Then, of course, it becomes interesting, well, you know, what's the wonderful things about it?
What are the great moments of your book-reading life?
And are these gone if we're in this space, or can we somehow find a way to...
to do the same thing here, is it possible?
And that's kind of the challenge.

Of course, I'm dealing with very modest writers, students for the most part, and there have been no great writers yet working in hypotech, so dealing with people whose books I read them, I'd have mixed feelings about.
Well, I'm not just talking about students, you know, there have been no great writers yet in hypotech.
No.
That's an important statement, right?
In my second review, which you've read, I review, at that time, all the extensions.
Nobody gets a big plus.
There's always a little twist at the end, even the positive reviews.
But there's good stuff, there's good writing, as good as most stuff you'll find in books.
We don't have a Joyce or Cervantes.
Of course, Cervantes was 150 years after Gutenberg.

know it may take a while before we find the committed writer who's so engaged and so understands the medium and so loves it that writes the thing that you know overwhelms us what would be the mark of genius in your view i'm not so sure i can especially when you're engaging the participation of the reader i can't i can't say for sure i know the things that have worked so far that suggest
I have no idea what, in the end, it will be.
One reason for that is that one of my frettings is the demotion of text itself, the diminution of its importance and power.
I'm struggling against that, but this may, in the future, look like a

Dinah Saurik struggled, and it may be that all narrative in the future will be multimedia, and that this idea of text alone will be an old-fashioned idea that will be revisited like a kind of scholarly or playful exercise.
I hope not, because what I feel to be the most interactive thing we do is
look at those little squiggles on a page or screen and convert them in our heads into vast landscapes and complex characters and all sorts of things that happen inside our heads just by
reading these little coded things here.
Just putting a few of your words out in these articles, you say, fluidity, contingency, indeterminism, plurality, discontinuity, every kind of principles of paper text.
We have absolute, absolute.
Yeah, I'm not saying necessarily those are all positives.
I'm saying that they're reality.
And that, therefore, it's a little hard for me working pretty much
in the old print medium to foresee in 1990s exactly what great narrative art's going to look like in this medium fifty years from now.
Do you think this is inevitable in your view?
Oh, yeah.
Digitization is inevitable.
I mean, the minute I understood digitizing, the minute I got the little glimmer out of it, oh, yeah, I got this, it's going to be a total revolution.
It's just so obvious.
And, I mean, it may not be a revolution that lasts a million years, but it's certainly going to last for the next few hundred years, I'm sure.
And this characteristic, the characteristics of digital information, you have to be alert to and aware of to understand what's going to happen.
And that's all I've been trying to do, and what most people have been trying to do,

and there are a lot of prophets and a lot of people who are have kind of convictions about what's going to happen but so far i've not been convinced by anything yet i don't see it so what i work with my students are traditional concepts they're not they're not they are they emerge from print so we talk about voice for example because voice seems to hold our hypertext together when nothing else does if the thing is all fragmentary things at least
convincing and compelling voice.
Let's say a writer like Joyce who was working in this space or Samuel Beckett.
Just the texture of the voice itself would be compelling enough to convince the reader that it's worth carrying on through a space that is a little bit hard to map in the sense of
I don't know exactly where.
I don't know what page I'm on.
I don't know how much earlier I got to go.
These are questions that you run into or something.
And voice is a counterbalance against the feeling of dispersion and non-discontinence.
But that's one.
As I already mentioned, I'm already looking for

what creates organic unity in a work that is not a linear text, one of the answers to that tends to be that the narrative tends to be looked at like a physical space, not something that is strung on a line, but something that exists

here is the same kind that exists here and it's like books do if you reread a book you know books you go back i've gone back to the ulysses on donkey only many times i no longer go back to the from page one to the end i go back to the
where I want to go.
I know them well, and I can go at any point in them, and I can search out things and just think about those aspects of that narrative.
So this requires a fresh reading, a prior reading.
Yes, yes, it does.
But the fact is that it exists then in my mind as a landscape and not as a linear narrative as such.
I mean, I understand the linear nature of it,
And that can be true, although I also can understand its spatial aspect.
So if I'm inventing a narrative in hypertext, I will tend to think of it in some ways, perhaps, or I might possibly think of it, as a narrative that exists whole and instantaneously in space.
Now there are ways in which you can
important off-spaces that cannot be reached into certain spaces to the distance.
So you can create a kind of limited sort of linear direction to something, if you want it, if you need it.
Maybe you don't.
Your memory doesn't.
And the only way that the memory requires linearity is that it's a big geographical space, which you think is back on those years.
If I ask you to tell me, you know, well, how did you get into
how did you get into this work of writing, these sorts of books?
You wouldn't say, well, I was born on such and such a day, and I was born in a hospital, in a hospital at some point at a time.
You don't start that way.
You start, well, and you tell me an experience you had, and that experience leads to another.
And even if you're telling me, you're probably thinking of other things you're not going to tell me, but a flash to mind is what is all.
And this is all hypothetical experience.
And so if students work in a space that has a kind of

spatial concept already then it sometimes makes it easier to create a structure that has walls that has limits has a wholeness and it doesn't matter if the reader explores it all i don't need to explore the entirety of your memory nor do you for that matter to arrive at a rather full understanding of you or of whatever the issue is or whatever the stories we're talking about and um
All reading experiences are, by their nature, linear.
And so the linear experience is imposed upon this space willy-nilly.
You can't escape the way we live in time.
